security: Disclosing the identities and affiliations of individuals involved in anti-war movements, as well as the specific methods used to gather intelligence (such as through the 'SQUASH' source and collaboration with the Australian Service), could jeopardize ongoing intelligence operations and compromise relationships with foreign services. Revealing the distribution of this information to the FBI could expose intelligence-sharing practices.
summary: This document outlines plans for a National Anti-War Conference in Sydney, Australia, and a National Moratorium, listing invited and confirmed participants, and requests verification of travel intentions.
summary_one_paragraph: This is a memo from CI/Special Operations, dated December 29, 1970, concerning plans for a National Anti-War Conference to be held in Sydney, Australia, from February 17-21, 1971, and a Third National Moratorium on April 30, 1971. The memo, based on information from the Australian Service (source: SQUASH), lists individuals invited to the conference, including Rev. Ralph Abernathy, Noam Chomsky, and Coretta Scott King, noting those who accepted and refused invitations. It also mentions a request from the Australian Service for verification of intentions of Americans to participate in these events.
title: Plans for a National Anti-War Conference to be Held in Sydney, Australia 17-21 February 1971 and a Third National Moratorium on 30 April 1971
